Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Transformation of Self in Alcoholics Anonymous: A Japan-U.S. Comparative Study

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research experiences raised two sets of issues: how to reconcile coherency and systematicity in societies and groups with individual variation, dissent, and disagreement; and how to describe self-formation and transformation and account for how it occurs.

Many previous researchers have stressed group cohesion and uniformity within AA, with an eventual group socialization of doubtful newcomers. However, what struck me in Kyoto was not only resistance from relative newcomers, but also from oldtimers to group practices. Members disagreed on interpretations of concepts as well as their relative importance. Although there are guidelines for behavior within AA literature, they are highly contested.

Tension between structural similarities and difference within the city was also apparent. In Kyoto, none of the members I spoke to had been familiar with discourse on alcoholism as a medically treatable disease, and neither had they heard of AA, prior to direct contact with medical institutions. An oldtimer explained to me that in her estimation, 95% of the members in Kyoto were introduced to AA during their stay in an alcohol treatment facility, while the other 5% were introduced by a physician or health care consultation services of local government. Male and female members reported differences in their experiences that they attributed to gender, such as social pressure to drink, attitudes toward their drinking, and challenges to sobriety; e.g., most men talked about how drinking alcohol with coworkers was an expected part of their employment and other forms of male sociality, and quite a number of women additionally reported struggling with an eating disorder. On the one hand, common structural factors significantly influenced the contours of my informants' personal experiences and may affect how people form affiliations with each other; on the other hand, differences among their experiential trajectories and relative success in staying sober cannot be satisfactorily accounted for as variations on any social type. Focusing on common cultural, social, institutional, and historical factors cannot fully explain how and why some individuals develop alcohol-related problems, some persist in problematic behaviors, and others transform. Furthermore, the structural factors – Kyoto's medical institutions and biomedical, AA, and gender discourses – are not monolithic in their operations and effects.

Regarding self-formation and transformation, my observations this summer highlighted the importance of four issues: 1) everyday practical activities, 2) both conscious and unconscious engagement with the world, 3) materiality and objects in the environment, and 4) the semiotic nature of people's relationships with their worlds. I learned from my informants that alcohol and/or drugs were not simply a means for particular ends, whether pleasure or numbing of emotional pain; rather, those substances were something they had a relationship with, and were tightly interwoven into the myriad ways in which they related to themselves, other people, and their environment. The more time I spent with them, the more I was struck by the mundane, quotidian nature of much of what they shared with me as significant events from their past or as contemporary transformative events. These included incidents with families, at work, with peers, and strangers; being in certain types of places or situations; routine interaction with institutions, such as religious, educational, political, legal, or medical; having (or not having) certain possessions; remarks made by other people; and physical reactions to them by others.
